A few months ago, I read an article and watched a video about how African American students at UCLA's law school feel about their environment. What I read and saw broke my heart. No one should be made to feel the way these students feel.

Since then, there have been reports of other kinds of racial problems at that school and others around Southern California.

MTFT, I suppose one cryptic remark deserves another. Martin alluded to the Crimea (jumping from Ukraine to Russia) in referring to Syracuse ORANGE jumping from the Big East to the ACC. My reply suggests there is little similarity between the two.

A better analogy is the breakup of the Soviet Union with Latvia and Lithuania joining NATO.

Based on the results in the NCAA Final Four tournament this year, nobody benefited from the breakup of the Big East or the expansion of the ACC. And being the traditionalist I am, I would be happy to see the Big Ten without Penn State, Nebraska, Maryland and Rutgers.

MTFT -- rose pink and pea green? How lovely those would look on the football field!

True, but also note that trend across law enforcement in general. Failure to "immediately and cravenly obey" is becoming a very frequent way that citizens lose their lives at the hands of the police, or at least suffer a massive beat down. As always, the cops claim it's justified, or "they were afraid."

The Rodney King event sparked riots. Little more than 20 years later, we see worse events on a weekly basis, and now do nothing. Our children are subjected to worse, and we also do nothing. A lot has changed, little for the better, in this country over the last twenty years.

One striking aspect of Tasering, not only in schools, is how often the Taser is used against people who are obviously not threatening.  Another is how often it is used as the first reaction to what appears to be a possible threat.  Summarizing:  It is used freely, as if it were really harmless and anyone who doesn't jump on command were a dangerous criminal.  A gun in the hand of the police might be safer because it is not used as freely (or should I say it is less often used freely?).

I dunno, Stu.

The FBI, NYPD and other large metropolitan police departments have very long histories of surveillance of certain ethnic and religious groups, going back decades.

It's particularly alarming to see how racial animus in our daily national discourse has degenerated in the last five years, after decades of seeming improvement. The question I've been asking myself a lot is, had that improvement, that appearance of harmony, been only an illusion?

While I don't disagree that the sentiments against Muslims have worsened and become overt since 9/11, I think they've been strong for decades, due to one event or another.

Exactly. The great companies did not reduce their dividends during the great downturn of 2008-, actually they raised them continually (PG, JNJ, KMB, etc).  Buy those companies and others like them, ignore the monthly fluctuations, and hold tight.  You don't need to pay an advisor to do that.

Many years ago, I heard about managed portfolios. For most the min is $100K or more.
When I went to work for a large aerospace corp, we had an investment club, and weekly speakers. I learned that investing in funds was just giving money to someone, to do what you could do yourself. On the other hand, managed portfolios were managed by investors who have a stake in its value increasing.

So when I retired, I put my 401K money into Brandes, and TCW, . They did very well until the 2008 crash. I also took five year payout retirement, and put 3/4 of that in a self directed IRA. The TCW got rolled into the self directed IRA, the Brandes into Zacks.

The accounts I control have mostly value equities. Long term well established dividend paying stocks. I survived the 2008 crisis, did not sell. I stay away from boutique stocks like Twitter, and Facebook. I may not get the big sudden gains, but over the years, my investments have grown, and my income from them has increased.

Buy good solid long term companies that have a record of dividend increases over the years. During the depression, Kimberly Clark continued to pay, people still bought toilet paper. Canadian banks are good solid enterprises, as is Wells Fargo. Just forget the sky is falling crowd, read "The Single Best Investment," & "The intelligent Investor." Read all you can about the market.
Notice all the negative comments about the market, these are more opinion than fact.

You have no idea what you are talking about.
The FED had nothing to do with the 2008 crisis. Those hedge funds had bought derivatives like CDO, SIVs, CMOs, and other kinds of constructed bonds.

First, start by leaning what the Fed is, how it operates, and why. It has not created any bubble. The big bubble was created by those who collateralized debt, got it rates investment grade, and created a high demand for it. Nothing to do with the Fed.

Your advice of what to buy, is a shortcut to becoming almost rich, from being rich. I doubt you are an accredited investment adviser.

I hold a number of pharma stocks like Lilly, GSK, Sanofi, Merck, Astraenaca, and they have just sailed along. They have lost a few points this week, but will be right back in the next couple of weeks.

Biotech is still in the discovery phase, once they discover how to actually correct a genetic disorder, they will be better than oil.

Energy stocks are also good, people are not going to give up their coffee makers, TVs, or like around here, swimming pool pumps. Lighting expenses are going down thanks to LEDs, but my A/C and furnace still need juice to run. The Shaffer Cullen group looks good, and they have managed portfolios. I have Zacks for one IRA account, they are dividend oriented, but it is a portfolio, not funds. I do not like funds. Why? Well when I get a 10K I see a major holder is a fund. They buy the same equities I have, but they charge you to do it. I pay Schwab $8.95 a trade. So I pay $0.085 a share for 100 shares, or $0.0085 a share for 1000 shares, one time only.

@Rima: Yeah, the aftermath of 9/11 may have represented only a fleeting illusion but the cooperation of Americans of all races and ethnicities seemed to be a salutary phenomenon regardless of the reason for it.  Needless to say the election of a "Kenyan" president (and the hopeful sign that represented to some of us) only served to remind too many of our countrymen of the resentment they'd been nursing before 9/11 interrupted all of that.
Never owned or used any Apple product. I just don't like the 30% profit rule. I get along very well without Apple and so do most of us.

Very sad that Apple has stopped innovating. I mean, who even picks up an iPhone anymore and checks an email or has an app that tells them turn by turn directions.

It took many years for a mobile phone to become a workable computing device. And when it did, it happened because of Apple. For years, they made the best computers out there, demanded the best software integration, designed the best interfaces. They launched the tablet. And some want to say that they are lagging because some folks want bigger screens on their phones. Does anyone realize how idiotic this sounds to anyone who values what technological advances Apple has brought to the marketplace in the past decade?

I don't care much about the lawsuits, but please, spare me the whining of addiction to "this changes everything" mania. I've yet to see one single feature on one competing phone that made me feel Apple has missed the mark. Like Samsung better? Great. Buy one. But you are buying Samsung's version of an iPhone. Until someone else creates a device that I had no clue that I couldn't live without, I'll cry no tears for Apple.
I really don't think PEDs are going away, ever.  Especially in cycling, which is so brutal on the body.  I think we are chasing moonbeams here people.  Wish I didn't think so, but I do.

Have people lost their minds?  Tasering children?  Why are schools bringing police in to deal with unruly children?  I've read that police in some cases are handcuffing children to take them to the police station.  Adults have died from being tasered.  This is a totally outrageous and inappropriate method of dealing with children.  It is totally unsafe and and should never be used!
Two kittens would be less expensive and twice as hilarious as a puppy, can entertain one another during the day, and don't chew nearly as much.

In any walk of life, confession of wrong doing is the gateway to "redemption"--whatever that means.  What's difficult for anyone, not just a public figure like Lance Armstrong, is to look inside your own heart and do whatever it takes to find peace there and no where else.  As long as the guilty continue to waste away their time and energy worrying what other people are going to think of them, it is impossible to really wipe the slate clean inside yourself.

You write "Armstrong knew he wasn't good enough to beat the other premier riders on the Tour." Armstrong won seven consecutive Tours. Seven. That is astounding. Cheating could make a subpar athlete win 2 or 3 or 4. But if you win 7 consecutive, even cheating, you're good enough to beat other premiere riders.

Lance Armstrong is among the worst examples of the human species. He has his money. He is not in prison, unfortunately. He is a disgrace and should be in disgrace.
It seems that money will buy you journalists who will write something, anything to keep disgraced athletes in the news .
Armstrong would use anyone, and turn on anyone, if it suited him. Let's close this sorry story and move on. Armstrong turns ones stomach.
